STATEMENT OP:    ALAN KEITH SEAMAN




OCCUPATIONS      ASSISTANT CHIEF FIRE OFFICER




My name is Alan Keith Seaman.        I an employed by the South Yorkshire         County

Fire   Service   in   the   rank   of   Assistant   Chief   Fire Officer.       My major

reference is that of Firs Prevention/Safety, which amongst a great deal                of

other matters, encompasses safety at Sports Grounds.




I   have   been employed within the Fire service for 23 years and I have been

involved with fire safety matters since April, 1973.




I have held m y present post since Februaryp 1937.          Prior   to   that    I   held

several    specialist   Fire    Safety posts at both Divisional and Readquartere

levels within the Fire service.




I am a nember of the Institution of Fire Engineers.
                              SAPETY OF SPORTS GROUNDS ACT 1975




1.    The Involvement of the Eire service in the implementation of the safety

      of Sports Ground Act, 1975




1.1   The safety of Sports Ground Act (SSGA) was passed in 1975 following the

      publication      in      1972 of the Report of the inquiry into crowd Safety at

      Sports Grounds which            was    prepared    by   Lord    Wheatley        following      the

      serious     accident       at    Ibrox    Park    Football     Ground     in     1971, when 66

      spectators were killed on a stairway.




      The Home Office issued Guidance to Local Authorities under cover of

      Home Officer circular 150/1975.                                                                         Ex 1




1.2   The Safety of sports Ground Act gave the Secretary of                         State    power     to

      require     through       designation orders that safety certificates be issued

      to sports stadia with accommodation for more                   than     10,000        spectators.

      The      intention      was     foe the Act to come into force gradually through a

      phased programme of designation orders so as not to place an                            immediate

      financial burden on the smaller and less well off clubs.




1.3   The      first   order was wade in August 1976 and applied to first division

      football clubs and            certain     international      grounds.     The       Home    Office

      ic:a*c\»    c;tiSdance    to     local   j.uihorities       under     covsr    o?     hotm of.flet

      Oixcu'U'rr 130/'/6. fthsfi'.iclcl Wednesday's ground was dec.l'j.vitrjd ju                  >Vugui>i:

      197 8,     rxU’houcjh    the club waa not in the first division,, becanno oP ii-r;

      were designated in August 198b, following the                       Bradford    City       tootball

      Club fire.




                                            - I -
1.4   In 1976, the Home Office produced a voluntary code called the "Guide to

      Safety at Sports Grounds                   (Football)",       commonly       known      as    the    Green

      Guide.        This     gave     guidance        on    measures for improving the safety of

      spectators at sports grounds and extended the                           recommendations             of   the

      Wheatley      Report.          The     county council latsr contacted the Home Office

      regarding the application of the Green Guide and had been informed that

      basically        any     new    work       or construction had to be of a                    standard not

      lower than that set out in the Green Guide but that maximum flexibility

      had to be maintained in the case of existing structures.




1.5   The     former South Yorkshire county Council, as the enforcing authority,

      delegated its powers and duties under the Safety of sports                                   Ground      Act

      to     the    Tire      service       committee,           on 8th January, 1976, the committee

      decided that           their     functions          should     be    exercised       through        Officer

      Working       Parties      for       the     four    borough        council areas, consisting of

      representatives of the                police,        the     Fire    Service      and    the       building

      inspectors of the borough councils, with co-ordination being undertaken

      by David Vaughan who was the responsible officer of the                                 Department         of

      Administration.            He     also       took the chair and produced the minutes for

      all working party meetings.




1.6   in order to avoid duplication and                      division       of    resources,         a    primary

      authority         wa&     chosen       for     the     carrying       out    of     inspections,          rc-

      the     primary        authority       for     means of escape and fire? precautions.                      By

      virtuo of their general experience as a                         fire       and    emergency        service,

      they     were     able     to     £ive       advice        on this subject.         However, the Fire

Service did not attend and have not                         attended       football        matches        as     a

matter of course.




It was the practice for all disciplines to report to the Administration

Department and thereafter for a joint meeting of                              the     officer        Working

Party    to     be     held        after      which    the        agreed    recommendations           of all

disciplines were               amalgamated         into     a     report    by    the     Administration

Department          and        sent to the club(s).             Copies of all correspondence and

the minutes of meetings were sent to each member and                                 all     arrangements

for meetings were made by the Administration Department.




It    was     the     practice for the Officer working Parties to carry out two

inspect ions of the ground each year, ccmaofily                            known     as     "summer”           and

"winter"       inspections.              it was Fire service practice to be represented

by officers           from      both     Divisional         and    Headquarters           levels     at        all

meetings       and        inspections          whenever         possible.        This enabled a common

standard to be applied.




With the abolition of the South Yorkshire County council                                    on 1st April,

1986 enforcement in South Yorkshire was to paes                              to the four

Metropolitan          District         councils,          Rotherham,       Barnsley,        Doncaster and

Sheffield.          The Local Government Act, 1985 amended Section 3 (3) of thn

the      Safety           of      Sports       Ground           Advisory     Group         comprising           of

representatives from                police,        Fire     Service,        the    building        surveyors
    division       and   the    Health   & consumer services Department of the local

    authority.       The Home Office issued guidance           on     the     new   arrangements

    under cover of Home Office circular 7/1986.

      recjardi.ng the standards ncces^ary.

(ii) Paragraph (b) of the report dealt with the west terrace (including

         With     regard      to the west terrace, it was considered that due

         to the lack of depth of the terrace, the offer to reduce                               the

         spectator       limit      to     7,200        and with a discharge time of 6.6

         minutes it would have been                 unreasonable          to    insist    on     the

         provision       of      gangways or additional exits.                  There wae total

         atOY&aent lateraiiy             throughout       the    terrace        and   the      three

         entrance/exits           from    the terrace were well situated.                   At the

         time, the worst disaster/emergency contemplated wae                              one     of

         fire.      As     the    weet           stand provided a minimum                 of fire risk

          (because it was constructed in concrete) it wae accepted that

         theee routes would be available and adequate in an emergency.

         The existing gates in the perimeter fence were discounted for

         means     of    escape        purposes.         At   that tune the gates in the

         perimeter       fence     were         considered      to   be    there      for       the

         convenience       of     the           police for      crowd control             purposes and

          suitable as a means of egress fcr a relatively                          small     number

         of spectators in the event of a localised incident.




          It was noted that, subject to exieting crush barriere passing

         the tests, they would              require special attention in                 view    of

         the apparent sharp edges and corrosion.

o f tliosc g uidelines to fo o tb a ll g r o u n d s d u t i n g th e n e x t few years

Contents of letter dated 18.2.87 (SYCFS - D Bo«nes) were discussed and agreed that
these matters be taken up with the Club. With regard to the timber buildings
beneath stands, it was agreed that the Club be revested to remove or resite these
structures.
 Hit*- r^ e c i - to locked doors tinder the South Stand, it was agreed ti.ah .this mrttr:
'would b- dealt with under FP Act 1971. Fastenings to'sliding gates w*re also

"Stewacding and securing cf all gates ;«s discussed ar.d the Firs
 that existing arrangements wer* only acceptable subject to exits being atew*r=ea
 and unlocked during 100% of th, time that the ground was ia use for a designate*
 purpose, ftny relaxation of this would mean an insistence that panic fastenings
only* be proyidea.
Discussion then took place on areas of responsibility and ground inspections.
On areas of responsibility 0 Bownes'did not want to be tied down to individual
references and even indicated that his Department could not act independantly tut
must refer all matters to the Council Committee responsible for SASG act. Vmilst
all others present would prefer definitive areas of responsibility lallow.ng th.
there must be some overlap), David Bownes preferred to refer back to a future
meeting following further consideration of the matter.
on ground inspections, B Bownes referred to the recent Loros decision that grounds
should be inspected annually, he anticipated that this would mean a ouch nor*
thorough examination than the present system of bt-annual Inspections, and tnat this
 would be backed up by inspections during games.
 This was agreed by all present, but reservations about the suggestion that during
 game inspections be carried out by the whole working party were expressed by th*
 Fire Service. It was agreed however that one such ’during game inspection woulc be

Future Administration of the Council's Certificating Function

Following a thorough review of the legislation it has become clear that a
detailed administrative system needs to be. established in connaccior. wish the
Council's Certificating function. Discussions on this matter have been underway
for some time with the Police, the Fire Service, the Council’s Building
Surveyor and Che Director of Health and Consumer Services on the establishment
of such a system.

Accepting that the Council as the Certificating Authority wij.1 acS on the basis
of advice from experts (such as the Fire Service) the auestion arises as to how
that advice may be best formulated. In the past* the County Council organised
an Officer Working Party which was apparently us*d as a forum for discussion
between Officers prior to the final formulation of advice to che Council. That
particular working party also appeared to have soce decision staking powers.

As it is essential that meetings take place due to the pocential overlap of
requirements in many areas, ail the Authorities end Officers have now agreed
that it would be appropriate to establish a revised fora of the working party to
perform a similar function for the City Council. It is recommended that che
“Safety of Sports Grounds Advisory Group*' (which would consist of
representatives from the Police, the Fire Service, the Building Surveyor s
Division and the Department of Health and Consumer Services), would function as
a fooic /or discussion between Officers; its most regular use would probably he.
the discussion o? itens of advice to the Council before they are finally
formulated by the appropriate Authority. M e e t i n g or the Group would be held ai
the reouest of one or more Authorities and on receipt of a recuest the Head o:
Administration and Legal Department would arrang* a meeting and despatch a list
of iLens to be discussed. At the conclusion of the pasting a further list *-
iterss would be prepared and the details of action agreed to be taken by each
Authoritv would be noted.   It is then anticipated cha: derailed written advice
to the Council would be forthcoming and be acJad upoi as appropriate.

      the exit signs and have pleasure in replying to your points

      Para ix
           I find the exit signs were erected under the supervision
      of John strange who is still                                                   on holiday,                   1 have quickly
      looked through the certificate of ground safety and have not
     been able to find any reference to lettering si2e.                                                                                 Because
      you do not say which exit signs have not been sited in
"     accordance wi t h the plans it is a little difficult for w e to
      comment and I suggest this matter be left in abeyance until
      John Strange returns.                                         W i t h regard to the illumination of the
      exit signs, it ma y be that you are unaware that we are rewiring
      the South Stand and it may be that the signs you have in mind
      will be appropriately illuminated b y both systems when this
      work is complete.

    Para iii
         We have not been able to understand what it is
    w h i c h y o u say does not comply with the requirements
    o f paragraph 12 of the certificate.       The agreement
    w i t h the Fire Service (Mr. K- Jones) was set out in our
    letter of 12 December.        S o far as w e can see the only
    possible variation from that agreement is that because
    of the rewiring which is n o w talcing place tfe did not
    implement the agreed measures in the 'case of the two exits


    December.


    Para iv
         The fire warning system is complete except for the
     supply of the trickle charger and battery equipment.           These
    items were ordered some months ago and if the original
    delivery dates had been adhered to would have been installed
    b y now.      unfortunately the suppliers have failed to
     deliver on time.        We have been applying appropriate pressure
     and the latest information is as set out in the attached
     c o p y letter from our electrical contractors which was dated
     24 March.       A s you will see from this, two of the four
     outstanding items have ve r y likely been delivered by now
     b u t the signal indicator panel was n o t expected for four
     weeks from 24 March and the industrial batteries complete
     w i t h steel stand and ancillary equipment was due to be
     delivered by Friday, 25 April.


            I        understand that there is to be a meeting at the ground

                              EMERGENCE EVftCUftTICfl PROCBDOES


  The following notes of guidance are prepared and issued to assist all ,
  official stewards and others in a position of responsibility at the
  Hillsborough Stadium on the action to be taken and procedures to be followed
  in the event of the possibility of evacuetion of the stadium during the
  playing of a gamo when spectators a*e present. The notes are not intended to
  be a comDrehensive list of all the action necessary, but are for personal
  issue to" each steward and for retention by the steward for immediate ref­
  erence all the ^ hip ha/she is on duty at the stadium*

 It is appreciated that the reasons evacuation may become necessary are maoy
 and varied, but the most obvious are fires or information that explosive/
 .incendiary devices have been placed scoewhere within the stadiun/ground.
   H t information may be receivsd or discovered either by members of the staff
    T the stadium, or by telephone to the stadium, police, local or national
 newspapers •

  TT IS STflF.ffWa? E7HENSVSR- ^OGB.J^CgMTgSOtt-.IS. ESCSXVgP. T5^-RSS3^0MSIB1LI^,
  FOR TBE DECISION.TQ. SVACUA2S    Ok PART*OP* C£S* GSOONZT$ £ & $ $ - t f l T E - T E S S E N 2 Q R
  MANAGEMENT OP TS2 CLUB. (The senior police officer on duty Will be in a
  position to adviae as to whether the 'boob call* is likely to be genuine or
  not).
                                                                                             (
  Whenever such infcraation becomes known, £ message will be relayed to tha
  police officer on duty in the 'P. A. Commentary Box" at the ground, who, on
  instructions froo the senior police officer, and irrespective of whether
  ths natch is in progress or not, vill cause the record 'THaES BLIMP Hits to
  be played over the loudspeaker system*

  The playing of that record vill indicate to everyone present at the ground, j ’
  other than spectators, that a possible emergency situation exists.

           I * port of the regular pre-catch brief of referees and linesmen and
           both teams, this infomation should be passed to then so that the
           game officials are also aware of tho possibility of an interruption in
           play and the significance of the playing of the record.

  On hearing that record all club stewards will n * e their way to their des­
  ignated duty points on gangways/gates/ex its, etc. Those on exit gsues will
  open the gates and remain at that point. 'During this period senior
• officials will consider the nature of the emergency alleged end will decide
  to evacuate all/oort of the stadium Once that decision has been taken, but
  not until, the senior police officer on duty will cause a spoken message to
  be relayed over the "P. A. System" which will have the effect ofs-

   (1 ?   S t o p p i n g the ^ane and removing players from the field of play;

   <2 ?   Informing the spectators/officials of the precise nature of the
          emergency and its location if known, and requesting all or specified
          sections of the public to leave their seats and raake their way out of
          the ground by the nearest normal exit route imless specifically directed
           to do otherwise by means of the     A. System".          U
    IT IS STRESSED THAT NO EVACUATION WILL TAKE PLACE EXCEPT 13 EXTREME
    EMERGENCY AND ALTHOUGH THE PREPARATORY EARNING RECORD 'TSRES BLIND MICE*
    KAY BE FLAYED, THERE IS EVERY POSSIBILITY THAT INITIAL ENQUIRIES HILL
    ESTABLISH TEE PERPETRATION OP A HOAX, ETC . , AND JN THAT CSSS, INSTEAD OF
    A SPOKEN HESSAG2 TO EVACUATE, TEE FACT THAT THE F-iERGBNCY HAS PASSED
    WILL 05 IX D 1 C & T E D BY THE PLAYING OF THE RECORD - 'TEDDY SEARS PICNIC*,
    ON HEARING THIS 'ALL CLEAR' STEWARDS ON EXIT GATES AND GANGWAYS WILL
    REMAIN ON STAND-5Y AT THAT POINT FOR FIVE tlBRTTES BEFORE CLOSING TKE GATES
    AND RESUMING THEIR NORMAL DOTY POSITIONS.

    In the event of any steward/club official discovering a firs or receiving
    inforraation that an ereergency situation exists within the ground, he will
    irseadiately —

    <ii) Inform any police officer.

Dear Mr. Vaughan,                                              ••
                                             Safety of Sports Ground Act
                        Thank you for your letter of 20 January.
                        I believe the small number of points needing
clarification have already been*discussed between
John Strange and Mr. Sheriff.                                                        One of these refer to the
;J^a for a goal post type frame over the gates but this is
in fact already provided by the sheeting frair.e.                                                                        There is
also a small amount of rust staining^arising fro* misplacement
of reinforcement in the 100mm thick retaining wall.                                                                          There
is no immediate danger arising from this and an appropriate
maintenance repaid will be carried out.
        Turning now to the radial barriers on the West
terrace it is of course accepted that where there is a
crush barrier passing through or close to the radial barrier
it will make it easier for anyone who so wishes to climb
over.                   Nevertheless we believe it is not unreasonable to
leave the crush barriers as they are.                                                                   If all barriers
were removed back to a distance say 1.2m from the fence it
would m e an a 2.4m wide gap which is not protected by barriers.

1    stand the p o i n t s t issue is whether t h e encroachment into
     the gate w i d t h is at all critical—                                 T h e raraaining clear
     width is 3.300 mm which is equivalent to a six unit exit.
     Thus the theoretical number of people who can get out in
     eight minutss using the green book figure of 60 people
     psr minute per exit width is 5,760 shared between the two
     routes.   The stand capacity is of course 10,000 and in
     practice more than half ths number tend to use fhe lower
     exits since most spectators are reluctant to walk uphill
     to the uppsr set of e : < it stairways.                                  The picture is that
     fewer than 5 , 0 0 0 people will be trying to get out of
     exits which can accommodate 5,760 in eight minutes.

The purpose of the meeting was to consider the letter             9th April
  I p,             s E i s t v o o d & Partners relating Co the proposals or
S e Sheffield Wednesday Football Club to construct W o new banks of
turnstiles and variou/runs of fencing and n e g a t e s i n            “ h l" ‘
segregation of visiting supporters at che Leppings L=ne end «f the
Hillsborough Stadium.

       Considerairion of Proposals

For the attention oi: Mr. D. Vaughan

Dear, Mr. Vaughan,                            s
             Safety of Sports Ground Act 197S
                           Sheffield Wednesday Football Club JPLC
                   Thank you for your letter of 2 May giving the* comments
of the Officer Working Party on the proposals which we sent
 to you on 9 April.
I        In the interim period several of the points which you
Raised had already been incorporated in our latest scheme
which has yet to be considered by the Club Board.                                                                                              However I
would .ask that further consideration should be given to the
request in paragraph (c) of your letter for a second gate to
be installed in the radial barrier and for the new radial
barrier which you have asked for to have two gates.'                                                                                             If these
gates are meant for use in emergency it would mean having                                                                                                        a
steward in attendance on each occasion, the expense of which
would hardly be justified.                                                It is our view that in the event of
emergencyrspectators can be evacuated quickly enough by the
gates on to the pitch and by the normal exit gates at the rear.
We will of course be prepared to discuss the matter with the
Fire Officer’s staff should you so wish.
                                                                                                         Yours sincerely.

IZ-flAS ACBEED Chat, in Che first instance, Dr. Eastwood would prepare sketch
plans of the suggested roofed disabled facilities in front of the North Stand
for consideration by the Officer Working Party.

C.    Ground Inspection
      Ti)   West Terrace and Stand

The Police representatives confirmed that the revised segregation arrangements
to the r*ar of the Stand worked well on by far the majority of occasious.

Dr Eastwood pointed out that the segregation rail in the upper seated area* *
of the stand could be moved within .certain limits if the Police considered   J?
that this would achieve a useful purpose.

IT WAS AGREED

(a)   that the additional advertisement hoardings, at the front of the upper
seated stand area (nearest to the North-West Terrace) should also be securely
fixed to concrete wall;

(b)   that further areas of spalled concrete at the front of the upper           .• .
seated stand area should received-attention as matters of maintenance.

     ' (ii)   Worth-West Terrace                                        *


West Terrace should be securely fixed.

       (iii) North Stand

The area for the suggested coveted disabled facilities was inspected.

As previously- mentioned by Dr. Eastwood,-.the possibility of providing an
increased width access to the pitch area (between the North Stand and r.he
Spion KoP) for possible use by emergency vehicles, as well as f«r maintenance         .
by the Club was discussed. .The facility couZd be incorporated i n t o the
enlarged Spion Kop proposals relatively easily.

It WAS AGREED that, whilst the County Fire Service felt that such a facility
was not essential for their purposes, it could be useful for use by emergency
vehicles in certain situations and generally should be supported.

       (iv)   Spion Kop

Dr Eastwood indicated the extent of the work to construct-the enlarged,
roofed Spion Kop, and-confiroed that steps would be. taken'to prevent-
unauthorised access to areas where, work might be in progress duringjte ;
course of the season..     ^
Tc          r„„ad cha. the additional gate in the’pitch plrioecer.fenie'io the   ‘'
front corner nearest to the South Stand, with a stepped arrangements -
a s s i s t a c c e s s a n d egress, had been provided.


       (v)    South Stand

It was noted that the metal sheeting of the. wooden floor of the upper       -
portion of the Stand <*itb sprayed non-slip surface) had proved to be o f * n
acceptable appearance in use, and generally appeared to-provide a compromise
solution to the m o b i l i t y problems iuherent in such wooden structures.

IT WAS AGREED that its condition would continue to be monitored.

S a f e t y o f S p o r e s G ro u n d s A c t 1975 - S h e f f i e l d W ednesday F o o t b a l l C lub

I n November 1986 I a s k e d b o t h t h e P o l i c e a n d F i r e S e r v i c e t o comment on th e
c o n d i t i o n o f y o u r s ta d i u m h a v i n g r e g a r d t o t h e p r o v i s i o n s o f t h e 1975 A c t . I
h a v e a l s o a s k e d t h e B u i l d i n g S u r v e y o r t o make s i m i l a r comm ents b u t I b a v a n o t
r e c e i v e d teem a s y e t .

The P o l i t e h a v e i n d i c a t e d t h a t t h e y a r e q u i t e s a t i s f i e d w i t h t h e s ta d i u m and
h a v e i n d i c a t e d t h a t t h e d e g r e e o f c o - o p e r a t i o n w h ic h t h e y r e c e i v e i s v e r y
sa tis fa c to ry .

The F i r e S e r v i c e h a v e , h o w e v e r, m ade a number o f comments and I a t t s c h f o r your
i n f o r m a t i o n a c o p y o f t h e i r l e t t e r t o me o f 1 8 t h F e b r u a r y .        1 th in k th e l a t t e t
i s l a r g e l y s e l f - e x p l a n a t o r y b u t 1 w o u ld p a r t i c u l a r l y l i k e t o r e f e r t o t h e
comm ents w h ic h a r e made i n r e s p e c t o f f i n a l e x i t g a t e s . As you c a n s e e fro m t h e
l e t t e r th * T i r e S a r v i s s c r s c c r . c s m s d            t h e a l i n i n g S* t e *          W *
t h a t a s a n d w hen t h e y r e a c h t h e end o f t h e i r u s e f u l l i f e t h e y m u s t oe r e p l a c e d
w i t h o u tw a rd o p e n in g d o o r s . The F i r e S e r v i c e h a v e a l s o p r o d u c e d a d ra w in g (a
c o p y o f w h ic h I e n c l o s e ) t o show a b e t t e r a r r a n g e m e n t f o r s e c u r i n g t h e s l i d i n g
g a t e s a g a i n s t f o r c e d e n t r y fro m t h e o u t s i d e d u r i n g t h e c o u r s e o f t h e game. The
F i r e S e r v i c e f e e l t h a t t h i s h o o k t y p e a r r a n g e m e n t w i l l b e m o re e a s i l y u s e d i n
 t h e e v e n t o f a n e m e rg e n cy t h a n t h e c u r r e n t l o c k s , a b o u t w h ic h t h e y a r e v e r y
concerned.

      o u t s i d e d u r i n g t h e c o u r s e o f t h e g a m e . The F i r e S e r v i c e f e e l t h a t t h i s hook

Dear Sir,

Safety of Sports Grounds Act 1975 -
Future Administration of the Council's Certificatiag Function

Following a meeting on Tuesday 10th March I have given some further thought to
the above subject.
Many points were raised at the meeting but I think that the general feeliog was
that the roles of each Authority invoked in the systw. should be defined
perhaps along the lines adopted by the South Yorkshire County Council.

1 have no objection in principal to roles being defined in this way but I should
make it de a r that if it is agreed that particular Authorities adopt particular
roles then they will be under a duty to consult with other interested parties
S e r e there is ^ o v e r l a p of interest. As I s*e it the Authority which carries
* * 1 Particular role will ha.e the responsibility of advising the Council as
Certificating Authority on all .natters filing vithin that Lead Authority role.

I have drawn up a draft Schedule which attempts to define Lead Authority roles.


                i  s                          a s   n   ? - k 1   2      ™                                                                                                           l L
if there are any other matters which should be included in the Schedule.

Moving onto the question of inspections of stadia, this point was also ^ c u s s e d



 S J S .- 5 2 L ! y S ^ S                                          . r
 Sperformance"
    E S T inspections ts th*y would highlight the performance of the safety
 system at each stadium whilst it is in operation-                                                                                                       cont..*

                                                                                 T etex 5 * 2 4 3 < A d tn in im tio n & U e a l )
Perhaps "during performance" inspections could be arranged so that each
Authority carries out such inspections independently with s degree of central
co-ordination co prevent two inspections taking place simultaneously. As the
first 8Cep towards the development of a programme of inspections it might be
appropriate for me to arrange a joint inspection involving representatives from
all the authorities in order to provide an insight into problems which may be
encountered*

Hoviag <?a t o the "working party" structure X think it is clear from the meeting
of 10th March that some clarification of its status ia requited. It is
reasonably clear from the County Council’s records that the working party as
such w«s actually s decision making body presumably acting under delegated
powers. However, the normal City Council practice is that the principal powers
remain with a Committee or Sub-Committee (in this case the General Purposes
Panel) with routine matters being delegated to a Chief Officer (in this case
myself). I would therefore propose t o asJc the Panel to accept the working party
aa a forum for discussion*

I take a view that the lead Authority will be able to use the Working Psrty as
a useful forum for discussion prior to drawing up tbat Authorities formal view
to be submitted to the Certificating Authority, I propose that when an
Authority feels that a meeting would be eppropriate contact should be made with
my Chief Licensing Officer, Hr. Bownes, who will then make arrangements for Che
meeting to take place. An agenda will be prepared and circulated priot to the
meeting and at the conclusion of the meeting Mr. Bownes will prepare a list
showing the subjects discussed and the action to be taken by each Lead
Authority. This list will be circulated as well.

Would you please consider the points I have raised and let me have your comments
on them in due course; it will be necessary for me to formulate a report to the
General Purposes Panel on the administration of the Certification system.

Tours faithfully,




Head of Department

Dear Sirs,

SAFETY OF SPORTS GROUNDS ACT 1975 -
DRAFT REVISED SAFETY CERTIFICATE CONDITIONS

In reply to you? letter dated 7th July re the above, please find below
the observations of this Department

Ssction 9(a)   An additional itco agreed with Barnsley and Doncaster Councils
               in respect of their standard conditions ia that the ege
               ran^e of stewards should be 18 - 6 5 .

Section 10(a) Whilst specified in the green guids, it is difficult to
              iflaGise ho11 this task can be control!ad by stewards. This
              matter should be considered further.

Seetion 10(i) Reference should be made to the opening and securing open
              of exits on the inciation of any emergency procedure or
              a t t h e e nd oT a game and to assisting and directing spectators
              out of the exits.

Section 18     Add . . . "The emergency power supply should operate independ­
               ently of the aain power supply and come into automatic
               operation on the failure of the latter and be capable of
               maintaining the necessary power output for a minimum period
               of three hours.

Section 23     Reference to "compressed gas or liquid" should be amended
               to • • ♦ "flamable liquid or coopressed gas (except fire
               extinguishing apparatus)".

Section 2ft    Add after ’’whatsoever"    "whether combustible or not”.

Section 28     The old SYCC certificate required that the Police had knowledge
                of the whereabouts of the doctor.

Section 29     Again the old SYCC certificate required that members of
               the press, T.V. and radio were identifiable.
Section 35(d) This requires that the electrical installation be examined
              and a report submitted to the Council every 12 months.
              The same requirement should also apply to emergency lighting,
              and fire warding (including P.A.) systems.

S e c tio n        3 5 (f)   Sub   p a ra g ra p h   ( i i i )   re q u ire s   e m e rg e n cy   lig h tin g   to   be   te s te d
                             at least 24 hours prior to an activity. It would be preferable
                             that the original requirement of testing 3 hours before
                             s ti activity be maintained.

Two additional items for consideration are:-

  (i)      That a competent electrician employed or retained ‘oy the Holder
           shall be present during a specified activity.

(ii)        The Holder shall provide and maintain within the stadium to the
            satisfaction of the Council the access routes for emergency vehicles
            3hoon on the plans.

S C t g D ’J L g    -   In te r p r e ta tio n


Uhereas the old SYCC Csrtificate required certain natters (e.g. fire alarms*
o:;tinsuishers etc.) and the maintenance of these to be to the satisfaction
of the Chief Fire Officer, the proposed Certificate now requires thsse
to be to satisfaction of the City Council.

This Dcpartaent does not foresee this causing any problems subject to
espies of the required annual certificates of tost being forwarded to
us for examination.

If thsre are any queries on the above matters» please contact Divisional
Officer GrinsUav.

Also enclosed for your information is a list of sports grounds and indccr
sporta premises within Sheffield and known to this Department.

Yours faithfully.

 Your comments regarding the various items as listed are receiving our attention.
 However, your comments on sheet 7 stating that each new member of the Fire Service
 to the to the Officer Working Party puts forward different recommendations have
 been throughly investigated and our observations are as follows.
 Station Officer Woodhouse has attended meetings of the Officer Working Party since
 November 1 98 5 and for two year prior to whit Station Officer .Mlcock v,^s the ••
 responsible Officer.
 The only time when another Officer may have been involved was when Station Officer
 Woodhouse was absent for 13 weeks at the Fire Service College during late J986.
^tftation Officer Woodhouse has also been involved in Liquor Licensing Act work as well
^ i s Fire Precaution Act work at th« ground.
 It would appear therefore that the clubs remarks are a little exagerated, and every
 endevour is made by this Authority for continuity of fire precaution standards.

 tear Sir
 Please find enclosed naps shewing the routes to be followed by Liverpool
 and Nottingham fans attending the FA Cup Semi-Final at Hillsborough
 football ground on Saturday, 15 April 1589, kick off 3 pen.

 Persons attending the fixture have teen asked to arrive in Sheffield from
 10.30 am and congestion can be expected until between 6 and 7 pm.

Dear Sir,

Safety of Sports Grounds - Draft Revised Safety Certificate Conditions

1 refer to your letter of 13th August 1967 (your reference F?19/2/4:RG/EB) in
connection with Safety Certificate Conditions.

I now enclose for your attention a copy of Che final revised Safety Certificate
Conditions which as far as possible incorporate the comments made in your
le-ter. You Hill appreciate that the wording of certain of your concents has
had to be amended slightly but I hope that the objective has Done the less been
a chieved.

There are four points which require some further consideration:-

               (a)            You say In your letter that an age range should be specified in
                              connection with stewards. I think however that the wording of
                              Condition 11 should be satisfactory without stipulating an age range.
                              No final decision has yet been taken on this issue and you may like to
                              consider it further;

               (b)            police knowledge of the whereabouts of a doctor - I believe this is
                              adequately covered in Condition 7;

               (c) identlfiabilley of press T.V. and radio personnel - I am not sure of
                    the justification for such a Condition and wonder if you have any
                              further consents on it;

                (d) the attendance of competent electrician - again I wonder what the
                     justification for this Condition would be.

    Would you please let me have your comeats on the new Conditions in due course.

A
    Yours faithfully.




    Head of Depatcnent


                                                                                                                           734690 - Mr. Bownes

                      GUIDANCE FOR SAFETY C E R T IFIC A T E HOLDERS



 INTRODUCTION
                                                                       <*•
 This note lias been prepared by the Sheffield City Council in ;©rder to inform
 Certificate Holders as to che general background of the Safety Certificate
 Conditions. The Council in dealing with Safety Certificates;cakes advice from
 the Chief Tire Officer, the Chief Constable, the Director of’.pealth and Consumer
 Services and the Council4j Building Surveyor* These Officers/and the Council
 itself is concerned to see as far as possible that the spectators st any
 specified activities are reasonably safe*

” GUIDANCE                                                                    •
                                                                   . % T• '


  Where advice is given to che holder by any of the four Officers mentioned it
  should be acted upon in accordance with the time constraints given in the '
  advice. The holder is reminded that failure to take steps to ensure the
. reasonable safecy of spectators could give rise to a prosecution.

 The Chief Constable and his Officers have a particularly important role in
 relation to "public order" situations the correct handling of which should
 reduce any risk to spectator safety.

  The Chief Constable must therefore be provided with appropriate facilities at
  the stadium for control, crowd surveillance, detention and administrative
  purposes. These facilities are essential if public order is to be maintained
  and che risk to spectators minimised.

  The Chief Constable oust also be informed at the earliest possible moment of the
  proposed date and content of all specified activities so that appropriate
  planning can take place.

' In addition there must te consultation and agreement between the holder and the
  Chief Constable veil in advance of specified activities about the proposed
  methods of admission and the segregation of spectators. Consultation raust also
  take place if advance information is such that public order difficulties may
  arise. As a result of this consultation it is possible that the Chief Constable
  may require, for reasons of preserving public order, that the specified activity
  is "all ticket' or the specified activity should not be played at all at the
  Stadium or the day and the time of the specified activity should be changed.

  The Chief Constable should also be able to use whatever means are appropriate to
  exercise control over spectators for reasons of safety and as part of this
  control he and his Officers should be allowed full access to all areas of che
  Stadium.
